definitions.definition: to disagree strongly with somebody’s plan, policy, etc. and try to change it or prevent it from succeeding
definitions.sensetop: oppose somebody/somethingoppose doing somethingoppose somebody/something doing something

examples.text: This party would bitterly oppose the re-introduction of the death penalty.
He threw all those that opposed him into prison.
Do you support or oppose this proposal?
She is adamantly opposed to the war.
I would oppose changing the law.
Her father opposed her becoming a missionary.
The ban was initially opposed by the US.
The minister has consistently opposed any relaxation in the law.
We totally oppose the use of gas to kill any animal.
We would vigorously oppose such a policy.
He found himself opposed by his own deputy.

definitions.definition: to compete with somebody in a contest

examples.text: He intends to oppose the prime minister in the leadership election.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French opposer, from Latin opponere (from ob- ‘against’ + ponere ‘place’), but influenced by Latin oppositus ‘set or placed against’ and Old French poser ‘to place’.
